conversation.content: Hello doctor, I have abdominal pain and bloating, and I keep vomiting repeatedly.
May I ask if you can describe the location of the abdominal pain in more detail? Also, what is the nature of the pain—dull, cramping, or burning?
The pain is located in the upper abdomen, and it is a persistent dull ache.
May I ask about the characteristics of the vomitus? Was there anything like coffee-ground material or blood streaks? In addition, is the abdominal pain related to eating?
The vomitus was mainly gastric contents. I did not notice any coffee-ground-like material or blood streaks. The abdominal pain does not seem to be clearly related to eating.
May I ask what the results of your abdominal ultrasound and complete blood count (CBC) were?

1. Abdominal ultrasound results: gallstones, cholecystitis, and dilation of the common bile duct.  
2. Complete blood count results: white blood cells (WBC) 16.49 ×10⁹/L (H), neutrophil percentage (Neut%) 89.1% (H), red blood cells (RBC) 5.10 ×10¹²/L, hemoglobin (Hb) 159 g/L, platelets (Platelet) 232.0 ×10⁹/L.

Diagnosis:
1. Conclusion: acute cholecystitis with gallstones
   Reasoning process: 1. Persistent dull pain in the upper abdomen; 2. Vomiting; 3. Ultrasound showing gallstones and cholecystitis; 4. Markedly elevated white blood cell count and neutrophil percentage

2. Conclusion: dilation of the common bile duct
   Reasoning process: ultrasound examination shows dilation of the common bile duct
Treatment:
1. Pharmacological treatment:  
Ceftriaxone 2 g intravenous infusion once daily (anti-infective therapy)  
Metronidazole 0.5 g intravenous infusion every 12 hours (anti-anaerobic coverage)  
Anisodamine 10 mg intramuscular injection as needed (antispasmodic and analgesic)  
Omeprazole 40 mg intravenous infusion once daily (acid suppression)  

2. Non-pharmacological treatment:  
Fasting  
Gastrointestinal decompression  
Intravenous fluid therapy to maintain water and electrolyte balance
